attributes.description:
This map visualizes the fabrics and processes used to create the Laura Siegel Fall / Winter 2012 collection.  Throughout 2011, Laura travled through India & Peru collaborating with artisan communities to develop and produce her collection. 

Laura Siegel’s mission: To ethically handcraft easy-to-wear, textured designer pieces while enabling artisans in third world countries to continue their uniquely creative skills.

Visit www.laurasiegel.com or www.clothingtraceability.com to learn more!
attributes.tags: clothing, laurasiegal, fashion, artisan, india, peru,
attributes.title: Laura Siegel Collection Fall/ Winter 2012

attributes.description:
Artisan: Ismael M. Khatri and family
Craft: Ajrakh Blockprinting

The Community: For ten generations Ismail Khatri’s family has been making hand block printed fabric, known as Ajrakh.  The craft itself is over 7,000 year old, with ancient examples found on Egyptian sarcophagi. The artisans use only natural dyes found in their region of Kutch, India. All of Laura Siegel’s block-printed fabrics are made in collaboration with the Khatri family. Business brought to Ajrakhpur helps to rebuild the community, which was destroyed in the aftermath of the 2001 earthquake and devastated the region.
attributes.title: Block Printing

attributes.description:
Embroidered by: Madu-ben 

The nomadic Dhebaria Rabari tribe came to India’s Kutch region in the 13th century, but it was only 15 years ago that tribe elders banned the elaborate embroidery work traditionally performed by women. Heartbroken, Rabari women found a loophole in the elders’ decree, adding an extra appliqué step to their embroidery method that allows them to continue the work they love without violating the law.  Characterized by explosive color, rich texture and elaborate motifs mirroring their surroundings, Rabari embroidery is used to identify communities, sub-communities, and even social statuses.
Not only does the work support these women’s families, but by creating quality product of the craft these women love so much, gives them pride and livelihood.
attributes.title: Embroidery

attributes.description:
The Craft: Natural Dyeing, shibori, batik work
Artisan Group: Aranya Naturals, Srishti Welfare Center

Natural dyeing is a labor-intensive process that doesn’t incorporate any chemical treatments, ensuring the artisans long term safety and health while preventing harsh chemicals from entering the community’s water system.  At Aranya Naturals, the group uses repurposed natural waste from the region including Eucalyptus leaves and tea leave waste.

The community: A community of natural dyers, located outside the city of Munnar in Kerala at a welfare center rehabilitates physically challenged young adults. These young people are educated and rehabilitated at a Vocational Training Centre managed by the women of Munnar. The dyers take pride and joy in their trade along with the ability to use their skills to support their families.Laura Siegel continues to work closely with this community of dyers to develop vivid new colors and unique patterns while maintain traditional techniques.
attributes.title: Natural Dyeing, shibori, batik work

attributes.description:
Artisan Group: Qasab
Craft: Embroidery

About the group: Qasab is a collective enterprise by around 1200 rural craftswomen from 10 ethnic communities spread across 42 villages in the arid interiors of Kutch, channelizing traditional skills for dignified income by enhancing their centuries old cultural craft.
attributes.title: Embroidery

attributes.description:
Artisan: Shiamji 
Craft: Handweaving

Shiamji is a master weaver and one of the best in the region.  His family has been weaving for generations and work together while employing other weavers in the region.
attributes.title: Handweaving

attributes.description:
Artisan Group: Dhebaria Rabari
Craft: Traditional Embroidery work

The community: The nomadic Rabari tribe came to India’s Kutch region in the 13th century, but it was only 15 years ago that tribe elders banned the elaborate embroidery work traditionally performed by women. After finding a loophole in the elders’ decree, adding an extra appliqué step to their embroidery method that allows them to continue the work they love without violating the law.  Characterized by explosive color, rich texture and elaborate motifs mirroring their surroundings, Rabari embroidery is used to identify communities, sub-communities, and even social statuses.

Not only does the work support these women’s families, but by creating quality product of the craft these women love so much, gives them pride and livelihood.
attributes.title: Traditional Embroidery

attributes.description:
Style Name: Woven Jacket w/ Dhebaria Rabari Collar
Style # FW12B112
Visit: www.laurasiegelcollection.com


The people, the journey and the life stories have shaped Laura Siegel’s design philosophies and ignited her passion for creating soft textile experiences, with ease and layering, and focus on the use of ethical practices.


Siegel’s mission: To ethically handcraft easy-to-wear, textured designer pieces while enabling artisans in third world countries to continue their uniquely creative skills.
attributes.title: Garment Design
Knitting, weaving, and crochet work
